column4: Hi all. I am having weird issue: when I try to ping one specific IP that is not in the LAN, my laptop attempts to ARP it. How come? It's one SPECIFIC IP address.
You need the ethernet address as it is on the same network segment
It is _NOT_ on the same network segment
sorry, misread
is it just that one IP?
Yes, I can find easily other IPs in the target network, just this one...
is there a VPN involved?
Nope.
so your LAN is split into 2 subnets?
many subnets actually. Not exactly same location.
I can ping 192.168.2.Z, but not 192.168.2.Y, and tcpdump shows ARP requests for 192.168.2.Y, which is... Well.. WRONG.
do you have a route specifying how the 192.168.2.0 network
module000: My routing table has a default route, a 192.168.1.0/24 route and a 169.254.0.0/16 route.
you should add one for 192.168.2.0/24 too
Nah... The router takes care of routing between different networks.
The default route works with the other nets, just not _THAT_ host.
try prefixing with sudo
:) Not that noobish.
covering the bases
could restart network service, shoul wipe it clean afaik
Yep the ARP (incomplete) is gone with .../networking restart
